data.title: Descendants of William Lockwood (1769
data.text:
Descendants of William Lockwood (1769 - 1850) and Parcy Powers (1775 - 1854)

Fourth Generation

54. Jasper N. Lockwood 93,94,95,96 was born on 26 Dec 1844 in Madrid, St. Lawrence, New York, USA and died on 17 Mar 1915 in Los Angeles, California, USA aged 70.

General Notes: 1. In the 1861 Canada census he is living in Carleton, Ottawa, Canada.

2. In the 1870 census he is listed as J. Lockwood, age 23 and he is living in Tulare, San Joaquin, California.

3. The "California, Voter Registers, 1866-1898" database at ancestry.com has Jasper in Tulare in 1871and in Los Angeles from 1879 - 1896.

4. The 1880 census transcription at ancestry.com has Jasper as a widower, but the actual form does not indicate this.

5. In the 1900 census his brother Joseph A. Lockwood is staying with him.

6. From the "Hahn-Beamer Family Tree" at ancestry.com:-

Source: A History of California and an Extended History of Los Angeles and Environs p. 479.

Jasper Lockwood. The death of Jasper Lockwood, which took place at his home, No. 1910 Buckingham road, Los Angeles, on Mar 17, 1915, removed one of the pioneer railroad men of Southern California. Mr. Lockwood had been in the employ of the Southern Pacific Railroad from young manhood until his retirement at the age of sixty years, having been assistant superintendent of the road, a position to which he had risen from that of telegraph operator. He was one of the few men remaining who had ridden on the Golden Spike Limited in April, 1876, the first through train between San Francisco and Los Angeles..

On December 26, 1844, Mr. Lockwood was born in Madrid, NY and came west to Nevada as a young man, finding employment with the Southern Pacific Railroad there, with which company he was associated continuously thereafter until his retirement from actual service in California. In the Southern California city of Los Angeles he was one of the organizers and charter member of the Los Angeles Athletic Club, and of Pentalpha Lodge No. 202, F & A M . For six years he and his wife had charge of the Los Angeles office of the real estate dealer, George H Peck in the Lankershim building, Mr. Lockwood's own interest in real estate being evidenced by the fact that he built six houses in Los Angeles, three of which he occupied temprorarily. He was married in California to Mary B. Cord, who was born in Indiana but removed to the Pacific coast with her parents when an infant. Her father, Thomas A Cord, was a pioneer settler of Oakland, Cal., who later lived at Pomona, where he was a pioneer settler and where he was an extensive land owner. The one daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood is Nell Lockwood, the well known contralto singer of Los Angeles, soloist in the First Methodist Church of this city, and a pupil of Estelle Hart Dryfus and also of Cecil Fanning, the famous baritone singer of New York.

64. Florence M. Lockwood 18,19,109,110,111,112,113 was born on 21 Feb 1856 in Buck's Bridge, St. Lawrence, New York, USA and died on 5 Jan 1939 in Morley, St. Lawrence, New York, USA aged 82.

General Notes: 1. In the 1860 census she is listed as Florance M. Lockwood.

3. In the 1920 census, she is indexed as Florence Witherow at ancestry.com.

4. In the 1930 census she has been listed as Florence M. Witherby.

5. From http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/, the "Commercial Advertiser" published Tuesday January 10, 1939, Page 1 & 5:-

MRS. CHAS. WITHERBEE PASSES AT MORLEY

CAME OF EARLY FAMILIES OF BUCKS BRIDGE

Born, Florence Lockwood, in Old Stone House on , Road from Morley to Bucks BridgeMarried Charles M. Witherbee Jan. 26, 1881A Home Woman, Deeply Interested in Morley Library AssociationThe Witherbee

Family.

Mrs. Florence Lockwood Witherbee, wife of Charles M. Witherbee and mother of Carl M. Witherbee of this village, passed away at her home in Morley about 9 o'clock Thursday evening, after an illness of about a year, following a stroke. Funeral service was conducted at the home Sunday after noon at 2:30, the Rev. Arthur O Northrup of the Wesleyan Methodist Church officiating. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery, Canton. The bearers were old friends and near neighbors in the vicinity of Bucks Bridge and Morley, as follows: Otis Dandy, Leon Bartholomew, William Finnimore, William Rowen,Simon Westaway and Royal Westaway.

Mrs. Witherbee was born at the old Lockwood home, a short distance from Bucks Bridge on the road toward Morley on Feb. 21 1856, the daughter of John Murray and Sarah Hall Lockwood. Both the Lockwood and Hall families were of the early families of that section of the towns of Potsdam, Lisbon, Morley and Canton, all four towns abutting each other in that vicinity. The old stone house

which Mrs. Witherbee was born still stands by the road, on the bend of the river in the town of Potsdam, still occupied by a member of the Lockwood family.

Her early life was spent in the vicinity of Bucks Bridge and here Charles M. Witherbee of the Witherbee family of Morley came to court her in the seventies and eary eighties. The marriage of the two took place in the Lockwood home on Jan. 26, 1881, the Rev. Samuel Short, minister of the locality at the time, officiating. There are not many who attended that wedding nearly fifty-eight years ago who are sill alive today.

Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee in the succeeding years farmed it and for some years Mr. Witherbee was engaged in the making of cheese. About eighteen years ago they removed to the old Witherbee home at Morley as you make the turn before crossing the bridge on the road from Canton. Here at this time lived a cousin, Louisa I. Witherbee, a graduate of St. Lawrence University, class of 1873, who passed away something over a year ago.

During tha years following the coming to Morley Mrs. Witherbee has lived a quiet and home life. She was wrapped up in her family and the home. Outside of this she took a deep interest in the Morley Library and the Library Association and spent a great deal of time with this. She was president of the association. She might be likened in this respect to members of the band of devoted women who a few years ago brought into life Canton library and made it one of the vital things of the community.

She was a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church, but attended he Wesleyan Methodist Church of Morley on account of nearness and convenience in attending.

The life of Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee during all those years from that January day in 1881, was the ideally happy one. They were blessed with a family of three children, all of whom are now living and in health, having their own

families, a son and daughter residing in this village and a daughter, a resident of the town outside of the village of Canton.

The husband, Charles M. Wither probably Charles Miner Witherbee, the name Miner being that of his father. The name of Witherbee dates well back in the history of the town of Canton. It is recalled that two of the older Witherbees were Miner and Luther Witherbee, tannery men of Morley.In the early days Morley, like other

communities throughout the country, had among industries a tannery. The Witherbee brothers and the tannery at Morley are still remembered by the older people of

the town. Of the sons of Miner Witherbee were Joseph V., Luther, Daniel, Silas O., and Charles M. The three former, it is recalled, were all students at St. Lawrence University, Joseph and Daniel graduating, and Silas who was a

member of the class of '67 left St. Lawrence before graduating and entered Columbia University, receiving

an M.D. degree in 1867. He died within the month in the

Middle West at the advanced age of 92 years. Joseph V., long an educator in Brooklyn and principal of schools 69, 24 and 106, was of the class of '80 of St. Lawrence

and received a B.A. degree from Harvard in 1881. He is still living, at present at Winter Park, Florida, a neighbor of his old friend, Irving Bacheller, the North Country

writer. Miss Lois I. Witherbee, above mentioned as a cousin, was daughter of Luther Witherbee, brother of Miner, and a cousin of the four Witherbee boys.

Charles M. Witherbee is in his eighty-fifth year and in excellent health, well preserved physically ind mentally for one of his years. Mrs. Witherbee leaves besides the husband, Charles M. Witherbee, a son, Carl M. Witherbee, and a daughter, Mrs. Mildred Collins, wife of George Collins, both residents of this village, and another

daughter, Mrs. Cora Woodbridge, wife of George Woodbridge, a resident of the town of Canton. There

are also two sisters, Miss Louisa M. Lockwood of Bucks Bridge and Mrs. Mary Dowd, who resides with her daughter at Queens Village, Long Island. There are also a number of nieces and nephews.

Noted events in her life were:

 Occupation: Stuff Maker ? (1880).

7. From http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/, the "Ogdensburg Journal" published September 16, 1933, Page 2:-

SERVICES FOR MR. LOCKWOOD HELD TUESDAY

Prominent Madrid Resident Died Following Stroke

Madrid, Sept. 16John R. Lockwood died Saturday, Sept. 9, after a lingering illness of about ten years. On Tuesday, Sept 5, he had a stroke and failed very rapidly until the end. Mr. Lockwood was born in Madrid in the house now occupied by Stephen Merkley, June 9, 1859, third son of Wiilard Sawyer and Julia Giller Lockwood, and with the exception of two years in Norfolk, lived his whole life in

Madrid. He attended the Madrid School and was a regular attendant of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

In 1880 he was united in marriage with Miss Zipporah Westaway who passed away in 1900. To this union were born two children, Byron and Susie Lockwood. On Jan. 3, 1904 he married Miss Mary A. Robinson of Grantly, Ont., and she has tenderly cared for him throughout his sickness. Mr. Lockwood is survived by his wife, Mrs.

Mary Robinson Lockwood, one son, Byron, of Seattle Wash., one daughter, Mrs. Earl Hall of Albany; one grand-daughter, Jean Louise Hall, of Albany; and one sister, Mrs. W. J. Brouse of Madrid.

The funeral service was held from his late home Tuesday, and conducted by the Rev. Lawrence Heatherington, assisted by Rev. George R. Harland of Chipman.

The Rev. Heatherington sang "The Old Rugged Cross", a special favorite of Mr. Lockwood's. Burial was made in the new cemetery. The many floral tributes showed the high esteem in which Mr. Lockwood was held in the community.

The friends from out of town were; Mr. and Mrs. John Wade, Mrs. D. L. Daily, Mr. and Mrs. W. Buffharm and Mrs. Jeanie Westaway Farmer, all of Canton, Herbert and Gordon Gates of Rodman, Mr. and Mrs. James Robinson, of Morrisburg, Mr. and Mrs. John Robinson of Finch, Mr. and Mrs. George Cunningham and family of Chesterville,

Dr. and Mrs. Schwartz and family of Colton, Mr. and Mrs. P. W. Froats of Spencerville, Miss Louisa Lockwood of Bucks Bridge, Mrs. Minnie Doud of Long Island, Mrs. Charles Witherbee of Morley, Mrs. Webster Chandler of Ogdensburg, Mrs. Eliza Harper and daughter of Flackville, Miss Emma McGaw and Mrs. M. M. McGaw of Lisbon.

Noted events in his life were:

 Occupation: Miliner (1880), Painter (1900 - 1905), Salesman (1910 - 1915), Farmer (1920), Salesman (1925).

3. From http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/, the "Courier and Freeman" published Wednesday July 29, 1925, Page 8:-

MADRID NATIVE DIES IN BURLINGTON

JAMES R. LOCKWOOD PASSES AWAY. WAS THEATRE MANAGER

Madrid, July 29James R. Lockwood a native of Madrid but for many years closely identified with the business life of Burlington, died suddenly at his summer home at

Sunset Cliff Burlington, Thursday morning. Mr. Lockwood was born at Madrid April 4, 1865, and graduated from the Madrid High school later entering the employ of the Milburn

Wagon Company of Albany as traveling salesman. After an association of three years he resigned to accept the position as manager of Charles H. Childs & Company, who

were engaged in the wholesale and retail wagon and harness business at Utica, N. Y.

Twenty nine years ago he came to Burlington and became associated with his cousin the late J. H. Lockwood

buying out the wholesale and retail carriage and harness business of William Clark. For years his partnership enjoyed an enviable reputation for quality and honest dealings covering New England and northern New York.

In the spring of 1912 he sold his interests in the business, to J. H. Lockwood, and in partnership with E. R. Hutchinson he opened the Majestic Theatre, which partnership

continued until 1921, when the thearte was sold to the Gray Syndicate, Mr. Lockwodo continuing as manager.

He was a member of Burlington Lodge, No..910, B. P. 0. E., a member of Burlington Council, No. 231, U. C. T., and an attendant at the Methodist Church.

He is survived by his wife; by a daughter, Miss Lucille J. Lockwood, of Trenton, N. Y.; by a sister, Mrs. Webster L. Chandler of Ogdensburg, N. Y.; and by a cousin, the Rev. W. W. Lockwood of Hudson Falls, N. Y.

The funeral services were held it his late residence, 231 Maple street Sunday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

Noted events in his life were:

 Occupation: Carriage Merchant (1900 - 1910).

3. From http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/, "The Ogdensburg Journal" published Friday May 13, 1892, Page 2:-

Madrid News

Homer Lockwood died May 7th, aged 41 years, result of LaGrippe. Homer Lockwood was one of the young business men of Madrid, having been engaged in the hardware business here for some years until he had gained the enviable reputation of being an upright, honest

business man, was always diligent in business, fervent in spirit, serving the Lord and lived an honoured member of the M. E Church. He had an attack of LaGrippe about a year ago from which he never entirely recovered, the disease leaving him weak, both in body and mind. He

was taken to Burlington, Vt, for treatment, where for nine months all was done for him that loving hands and hearts could do, but to no avail. His wife was informed of his death by telegram while on the cars going to see him, He leaves a loving wife and five little ones, that will sadly

miss a father's love and tender care, while Madrid loses one of her best business men, which we can ill afford to do.

5. From http://www.onlinebiographies.info/ny/sl/lockwood-hr.htm

Biography of Homer R. Lockwood

Lockwood, the late Homer R., Madrid, was born on a farm in Madrid, October 20, 1851. Charles S. Lockwood, his father, was also a native of this county and was a farmer. Homer H. was his only son. He was educated in the common schools and withheld from a collegiate course on aoeount ot delicate health, He assisted on his father's farm until thirty years of age, then engaged in the hardware business in partnership with his uncle, Edward Lockwood, This partnership existed until 1890, when Mr. Lockwood bought his partner's interest, and continued the business alone until April, 1891. He then left the store in hopes of recruiting his health. But these hopes werc false, as he gradually declined and while in Burlington, Vt, where he had gone to be under the care of a specialist, he died, May 7, 1892. Mr. Lockwood was a man of considerable influence in this town and always took an active interest in school and church work. He was a member of the hoard of education for three years, an officer of the Methodist church, and its Sunday school superintendent a number of years. By his death the church lost one of its most active workers, the town an admirable citizen, and his family a loving husband and father. He married in 1878, Minnie, daughter of John Sullivan, of Louisville, who, with five children, survives him. The children are: Jessie Anna, Howard Charles, Frank Homer, Ruth Elizabeth and Harold Rollin.

FROM: Our County and it's people

A memorial record of St. Lawrence County, New York

Edited by: Gates Curtis. The Boston History Co., Publishers 1894

(a) the "Norwood News" published Wednesday August 04, 1937, Page 1:-

Rev. W. W. Lockwood Dies at Glen Falls

Rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church Here for 9 Years

A telegram was received here Thursday announcing the death of Rev. William W. Lockwood at Glens Falls, N. Y. His death was sudden. The message did not state the cause.

Rev. Mr. Lockwood was born in Madrid 70 years ago, the son of William and Marie Loucks Lockwood. He was an Episcopal rector of St. Philip's church here for nine years, and for 15 years at Hudson Falls, after which he went to Glens Falls as assistant at the Church of the Messiah.

He married Minnie Wells of Madrid who survives with one son, James Morrison Lockwood, of Washington, D. C.

(b) the "Norwood News" published April 27, 1938, Page 1:-

Tablet is Unveiled In Memory of Rector

Memorial to Rev. W. W. Lockwood is Dedicated in Zion Episcopal Church

Hudson Falls, April 25.-With most appropriate exercises in the presence of members of Zion Episcopal church

and persons of all religious creeds in Hudson Falls, a bronze tablet in memory of the late Rev. William Wallace

Lockwood, rector of the church for more than twenty years, was unveiled and deicated by the Rev. L Hugh Hooper, rector, at the 11 A. M. service yesterday.

The Rev. Lockwood came to the Hudson Falls pastorate in the spring of 1904. In 1924, due to failing health he resigned as rector of the church and after a rest answered the call of the Rev. Oliver S. Newell to become assistant at the Church of the Messiah in Glens Falls. The Rev. Lockwood studied for Holy Orders and was ordained deacon in St. Paul's church at Waddington, N. Y. on Trinitv Sunday 1894, by the Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, D.D., bishop of Albany. He was ordained to the priesthood by Bishop Doane in 1897 and spent his ministry in missionary work at Fine and Norwood until 1904.

S. R. LOCKWOOD PASSES AWAY AT MADRID

MadridSylvenus R. Lockwood, 69, died at his home Thursday morning at 5 following an illness of several weeks. Mr. Lockwood had been in declining health since last August when he sustained a foot injury. At that time he was taken to Hepburn Hospital where he remained

for eight weeks after which he was removed to his home. Complications developed about three weeks ago which caused his death.

Born Sept. 9, 1872 in Madrid. Mr. Lockwood was a son of Milo and Harriet Lockwood. He attended schools in Madrid. When he was 14 years of age his brothers and

sisters died of diphtheria and a year later his mother died.

Mr. Lockwood married Miss Gertrude Simons of Madrid on

Nov. 25, 1896. He was a dealer in farm produce in this area and also was secretary and treasurer of the Dr. Williams Fly and Insect Destroyer Company from the time of its formation until its liquidation two years ago. He was a deputy sheriff of the country for more than 30 years and a town officer for 35 years.

Surviving are his wife and a daughter, Miss Mildred Lockwood, of Brooklyn. Funeral services will be held Sunday afternoon at 2 from the home with the Rev.

Emerson Emke, pastor of the Congregational Church, officiating.

6. From http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/, the "Ogdensburg Journal" published Monday March 08, 1965, Page 5:-

Mrs. G. L. Frauton Dies At Hospital Here At Age 90

Morley  Mrs. Gertrude Lockwood Frauton, 90, died Sunday morning at 3:30 at the St. Lawrence State Hospital where she had been a patient for the past three years.

years.

The body is resting at the Gardner Funeral Home where friends may call today from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9.

The funeral will be held Tuesday at 2 p.m. at the Morley

Methodist Church. The Rev. Ray Morgan will officiate.

Burial in Morley Cemetery.

She is survived by three cousins, Mrs. Wright Davidson

of Ogdensburg; Charles Todd of Morley and Donald

Todd of Canton.

She was born in Morley, Sept. 28, 1874, a daughter of

Dempster and Fredonia Ellison Lockwood. She attended

Morley schools and was graduated from Potsdam Normal.

She taught school in Morley and Rensselaer Falls. She was married to Elmer Frauton on June 30, 1898. He died June 30, 1923.

She was a member of the Morley Methodist Church and

was organist there for 50 years. She was also a member

of the Morley Missionary Society.
